messageBody:
Hi,

as a waring: I am not familiar with the framworks you use.
I assume you are waiting for Quartz to call a method
in one of your tested code, right?
In cases like this I call the method directly from the test code.

HTH

Bernd


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Schuerig [mailto:michael@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, December 22, 2004 1:31 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Multithreading: Testing scheduled method invocation?!
>
>
>
> I'm working on a class that interacts with the Spring framework's
> application context and the Quartz scheduler. I'm pretty new to the
> latter, thus I'm testing my understanding of Quartz just as
> much as I'm
> testing my code. In effect, I can't (yet) build the fixture
> for my code
> completely with mocks as I have to ascertain what these mocks are
> supposed to do first.
>
> The complication here is that Quartz uses its own "hidden"
> thread(s) to
> fulfill its duties. It is such a thread that effects the
> change that I
> need to check for. As I don't want to test Quartz, of course, I'm
> content with checking that my scheduled job is executed at
> all. Thus I
> schedule it for immediate execution, wait for 2 secs to give Quartz
> some time before the fixture is torn down again.
>
> Now, all this works surprisingly well. Still, I don't like
> the part of
> waiting some arbitrary time.
>
> (Thinking break)
>
> After getting this far, I remembered that Doug Lea's
> concurrency utils
> have made their way into J2SE 5.0 and there I found just what
> I needed:
> java.util.concurrent.CountDownLatch
>
> Now I have a TestCase that looks in outline like this
>
>
> public class MultiThreadedTest extends TestCase {
> private static CountDownLatch latch;
> private MyMock mock;
>
> protected void setUp() {
> latch = new CountDownLatch(1);
> mock = new MyMock();
> }
>
> public void testMe() throws Exception {
> startSomeWorkInAnotherThread(mock);
> latch.await(); // some timeout might be prudent
> mock.verify();
> }
>
>
> private static class MyMock implements Whatever {
> private boolean wasCalled = false;
>
> public void methodCalledFromOtherThread() {
> wasCalled = true;
> latch.countDown();
> }
>
> public void verify() {
> assertTrue(wasCalled);
> }
> }
> }
>
>
> I appreciate your comments.
>
> Michael
